content.description: A childhood condition characterized by severe, recurrent temper outbursts (verbal or behavioral) that are grossly out of proportion to the situation, along with persistently irritable or angry mood between outbursts. Symptoms are present for at least 12 months, occur in multiple settings, and are inconsistent with developmental level.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Severe recurrent temper outbursts manifested verbally (e.g., verbal rages) and/or behaviorally (e.g., physical aggression toward people or property) grossly out of proportion in intensity or duration to the situation. B. Outbursts inconsistent with developmental level. C. Occur on average three or more times per week. D. Mood between outbursts is persistently irritable or angry most of the day, nearly every day. E. Criteria present for 12+ months without symptom-free period >3 months. F. Present in at least two settings and severe in at least one. G. Onset before age 10; diagnosis not made before age 6 or after age 18. H. Symptoms not exclusively during major depressive episode and not better explained by another disorder (e.g., autism, PTSD, separation anxiety, persistent depressive disorder). I. Not attributable to substance/medical condition.
content.prevalence: Estimated 2–5% of children and adolescents; more common in males and school-aged populations.
content.age_of_onset: Before age 10, diagnosis typically made in school-age children or early adolescence.
content.prognosis: High risk for later unipolar depression and anxiety disorders rather than bipolar disorder. Symptoms may lessen with age, but irritability and mood dysregulation can persist. Functional impairment in academic, social, and family domains is common.

circuitry: Aberrant activity in the amygdala, anterior cingulate cortex, and prefrontal cortex, leading to poor emotional regulation and heightened threat perception.
Deficits in prefrontal–limbic connectivity impair top-down modulation of affect.
neurochemistry: Dysregulation of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine pathways.
Possible HPA-axis overactivation contributing to irritability and stress reactivity.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Genetic predisposition to mood disorders and ADHD; early life adversity, inconsistent parenting, and chronic stress increase vulnerability.

history_psychosocial: Detailed timeline of irritability, mood changes, and outbursts across settings.
Collateral reports from parents, teachers, and other caregivers.
Assessment of triggers, family dynamics, and comorbid conditions.
medical_assessment: Physical exam and neurological assessment to exclude medical causes.
Labs if indicated to rule out thyroid dysfunction, seizure disorders, or other relevant conditions.
standardized_measures: Kiddie Schedule for Affective Disorders and Schizophrenia (K-SADS) modules for DMDD and comorbidities.
Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) to quantify irritability and aggression.
Mood Dysregulation Disorder schedule where available.
risk_stratification: Assess for suicidal ideation, self-harm, and aggression toward others.
Consider need for higher level of care if safety concerns arise.
differential_diagnosis: Bipolar disorder (episodic mood changes rather than chronic irritability).
Oppositional defiant disorder (less severe irritability, absence of persistent mood disturbance).
ADHD (primary attentional and hyperactive symptoms rather than mood-driven).
Autism spectrum disorder (social communication deficits as primary impairment).
Intermittent explosive disorder (less persistent mood disturbance).
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborate with school, family, and mental health providers to create a consistent management plan across settings.

core: Persistent irritability or anger between outbursts
Mood disturbance present in multiple settings
associated: Academic underachievement related to mood symptoms

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms present in one setting (home, school, or with peers).
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms present in at least two settings.
severity_levels.severe: Symptoms present in all settings with severe impairment.

biological: Family history of mood disorders or ADHD
environmental: Chronic family conflict or inconsistent parenting
Exposure to trauma or ongoing stress

impact_on_life.social: Peer rejection, social isolation, bullying involvement.

psychotherapy: Parent management training (PMT) to improve consistency and reduce reinforcement of irritability.
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) focusing on emotional regulation and problem-solving skills.
Dialectical Behavior Therapy for Children (DBT-C) to teach mindfulness and distress tolerance.
School-based interventions for behavior support and social skills.
medications: Stimulants (methylphenidate, amphetamines) if ADHD comorbidity present; may reduce irritability indirectly.
SSRIs (fluoxetine, escitalopram) for co-occurring anxiety or depressive symptoms.
Atypical antipsychotics (risperidone, aripiprazole) for severe aggression/irritability unresponsive to behavioral interventions.
Mood stabilizers (valproate, lithium) considered in refractory cases with significant mood instability.
lifestyle_interventions: Consistent sleep routine and physical activity.
Minimizing overstimulation and providing predictable schedules.
care_coordination: Regular communication between family, school, and clinicians.

treatment_goals: Reduce frequency and severity of outbursts.
Enhance functioning across home, school, and peer settings.
Reduce family stress and improve relationships.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Symptoms attributed solely to ADHD or ODD without assessing persistent irritability.
Overlooking the chronic nature of mood disturbance between outbursts.
overdiagnosis_factors: Mislabeling normal developmental tantrums in preschoolers as DMDD.
Confusing episodic mania/hypomania with chronic irritability.
Diagnosing without adequate duration of symptoms (12 months).

course: May evolve into unipolar depression or anxiety disorders in adolescence/adulthood

warning_signs: Escalating aggression or threats of harm.
School expulsions or suspensions due to outbursts.
Emergence of depressive symptoms or suicidal ideation.

childhood: Outbursts triggered by minor frustrations; disruptive at school and home.
adolescence: Irritability may manifest as verbal aggression, defiance, and school refusal.

real_life_examples: An 8-year-old boy with daily meltdowns at home and school, throwing chairs when frustrated, and remaining angry most of the day between incidents.
A 13-year-old girl who becomes verbally abusive toward teachers over perceived slights, with chronic irritability and frequent peer conflicts.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek professional help when mood disturbance and outbursts are persistent, occur across settings, and significantly impair functioning. Immediate intervention is needed if there is self-harm, aggression toward others, or suicidal ideation.
